Star Tribune Investigation Reviews Trump Administration's 'Worst of the Worst' Immigrant List in Minnesota
item.description: The Trump administration has highlighted a group of immigrants detained in Minnesota during Operation Metro Surge, which began in December and resulted in approximately 3,000 arrests, describing them as the 'worst of the worst'—violent criminals such as assailants, domestic abusers, and drug traffickers allegedly enabled by the state's sanctuary policies. Federal officials, including President Trump at a White House news conference, publicized a list of about 240 names, often accompanied by mugshots, to emphasize the severity of the threats posed by these individuals. However, a detailed investigation by the Minnesota Star Tribune, reviewing thousands of pages of court documents, prison records, and other public sources, presents a more complex reality. Roughly 80% of those listed have felony convictions, including serious crimes like murder, rape, assault, drug offenses, theft, and fraud. item.title: Macron announces €300 billion European savings to be invested locally with the establishment of the S&I Union
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron announced a major financial initiative aimed at retaining European capital within Europe. According to Macron, approximately €300 billion of European savings, which have historically been invested in the United States each year, will now be redirected to support investments within the European Union. This decision comes after a unanimous agreement among all 27 EU member states to establish the S&I Union, which represents a significant step toward creating a fully integrated European Capital Market. The move is expected to strengthen Europe's economic independence, increase investment opportunities within member states, and foster financial stability across the region. Experts suggest that by redirecting these funds, Europe could see enhanced funding for infrastructure projects, technological innovation, and sustainable development. item.title: Structural Challenges Threaten Spanish High-Speed Rail Network
item.description: The article discusses potential causes behind a recent derailment on the high-speed rail line near Adamuz, Spain. The author analyzes the failure of a specific rail section near a weld and suggests that the accident may not be an isolated incident but rather indicative of a structural problem. Observations indicate that thermal tension or pre-existing cracks were unlikely contributors, leaving possible welding defects or steel processing issues as likely causes. Beyond this individual failure, the article highlights broader issues with Spain's high-speed rail network, which was designed for lower traffic volumes and lighter trains. The network is now operating under stress from heavier trains and increased traffic, raising maintenance challenges that may be economically and operationally unsustainable. Possible solutions include reducing train weight and frequency or upgrading infrastructure to meet higher demands, both of which would be costly and could be perceived as a major setback

item.title: Kim Kardashian Clarifies Elephant-Skin Birkin Bag Was Fake Prop on 'All's Fair' Set, Regrets Not Addressing Backlash Sooner
item.description: Kim Kardashian recently addressed a viral controversy surrounding a Hermès Birkin bag that appeared to be made from elephant skin, which she carried while filming her Hulu legal drama series 'All's Fair.' The accessory sparked significant outrage in November 2025 from animal rights groups and celebrities like Ireland Baldwin, who called it 'disgusting and shameful,' due to ethical concerns over exotic animal materials in luxury fashion and Hermès' alleged past use of elephant hides from the 1980s. Initially, Kardashian remained silent, citing feeling overwhelmed by the negative reactions and concurrent scrutiny over her show. In a January 2026 episode of her sister Khloé Kardashian's podcast 'Khloé in Wonder Land,' she explained that the bag was not from her personal collection nor authentic. Instead, it was a prop brought in for wardrobe purposes during filming, along with other replica items left on set for convenience in styling scenes. She noted visible signs it was fake, such as u

item.title: Goldman Sachs Questions Generative AI's Economic Viability Amid Massive Investments and Limited Returns
item.description: Goldman Sachs released a research report titled 'Gen AI: too much spend, too little benefit?' that casts doubt on the massive investments in generative AI infrastructure. The bank estimates that tech companies and others will spend around $1 trillion on AI-related capital expenditures, including data centers, chips, and power grid enhancements, yet there is currently little tangible benefit or evidence of payoff. Drawing from interviews with Goldman Sachs economists, MIT professor Daron Acemoglu, and infrastructure experts, the report highlights concerns about whether scaling training data further will resolve core issues, as data quality matters more than quantity and high-quality sources may be scarce. Jim Covello, head of global equity research at Goldman Sachs, expressed strong skepticism, noting that generative AI remains unreliable for even basic tasks like summarization, often producing nonsensical results, and cited internal tests where AI was six times more expensive than manu

item.title: Minneapolis General Strike Inspires Solidarity Actions in Over 120 Cities Nationwide
item.description: The Minneapolis General Strike, initially organized by the Minneapolis Regional Labor Federation and the Minnesota AFL-CIO, is rapidly gaining national attention. Workers across Minnesota have planned a 'Day of Truth and Freedom' strike, with thousands expected to participate in the Twin Cities. This local strike has inspired solidarity actions in at least 120 cities across the United States, signaling a growing labor movement against ICE operations in Minneapolis. Payday Report has been tracking these solidarity events and has provided an interactive map to visualize the nationwide participation. The movement reflects collaboration among labor unions, community organizations, and immigrant rights groups, aiming to create a model for collective action against federal raids. According to CWA Local 7520 President Keiran Knutson, tens of thousands of workers could join in Minnesota, with similar mobilizations appearing in other regions. item.title: Top 1% of US Households Reach Record 31.7% Share of Wealth in Q3 2025, per Federal Reserve Data
item.description: According to recent Federal Reserve data, wealth inequality in the United States has reached its highest level in over three decades. In the third quarter of 2025, the top 1% of households owned 31.7% of all U.S. wealth, the largest share recorded since tracking began in 1989. This group held approximately $55 trillion in assets, roughly matching the combined wealth of the bottom 90% of Americans. The trend highlights a persistent K-shaped economic recovery, where low- and middle-income households experience stalled or slowed wealth growth, while the richest pull further ahead. Experts attribute the widening gap to several factors, including surging stock market gains driven by investments in artificial intelligence, which disproportionately benefit wealthier households with higher stock ownership. In contrast, middle-income families have more wealth tied to real estate, where price growth has moderated. Uneven wage increases also play a role, with higher-income groups seeing stronger

item.title: Trump Drops Greenland Tariff Threats After Davos Speech and NATO Talks, But Tensions Persist with European Leaders
item.description: In his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos on January 21, 2026, US President Donald Trump reiterated his desire for the US to acquire Greenland from Denmark, framing it as a reasonable transaction due to historical US military support to Europe and criticizing allies for not contributing enough to NATO. He claimed the US had been wrong to 'give back' Greenland after World War II (a historical inaccuracy, as Greenland was never US territory) and mocked several leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron. Trump ruled out using military force to take Greenland but insisted on negotiations for outright ownership. He also referenced a quip that without the US, Europeans would be 'speaking German,' which drew criticism for being insulting and inaccurate, especially in multilingual Switzerland. Initially, Trump threatened 10% tariffs starting February 1 on goods from eight European countries (including Denmark, Germany, France, UK, and others) opposing his Greenland ambitions.

item.title: Kyiv Faces Mass Exodus Amid Russian Strikes on Energy Infrastructure and Severe Winter Blackouts
item.description: In January 2026, Kyiv experienced intense Russian missile and drone attacks targeting energy infrastructure, resulting in widespread power, heating, and water outages across the capital and nearby regions like Chernihiv. Ukrainian officials reported that up to 80% of Kyiv lost electricity, with over a million residents affected and many buildings without heat during temperatures plummeting to -18°C in a prolonged cold snap. Mayor Vitali Klitschko announced that around 600,000 people had fled the city in January alone, based on mobile phone data, out of a pre-war population of roughly 3 million, equating to a 20-25% decline. Authorities urged further evacuations to avoid a humanitarian crisis, while considering shutting down the metro to conserve power. The parliament operated remotely due to uninhabitable conditions in the building, and nuclear power plants remained the primary electricity source amid accusations that Russia might target them. item.title: Minnesota ICE agents accused of targeting off-duty officers of color during enforcement
item.description: Brooklyn Park Police Chief Mark Bruley reported that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents in Minnesota have been involved in incidents where they stopped off-duty police officers of color, pulled guns on them, and demanded proof of citizenship. These encounters occurred even though the officers were U.S. citizens and in some cases attempted to record the interactions. Bruley stated that this behavior is part of a broader pattern of civil rights complaints received from the community, noting that if trained officers who understand constitutional rights are being targeted, it raises serious concerns for the general public. He emphasized that these incidents are not isolated, with other law enforcement chiefs confirming similar experiences with their off-duty officers. Bruley criticized the manner in which ICE is enforcing immigration laws, though he clarified that he does not support abolishing the agency entirely. item.title: Bank of America relaunches Air France/KLM Flying Blue Visa with 70,000-mile bonus plus 100 XP
item.description: Bank of America has reintroduced a strong welcome offer for the Air France/KLM World Elite Visa Signature credit card, providing 70,000 Flying Blue miles and 100 Experience Points (XP) after spending $3,000 within the first 90 days of account opening. This matches the highest bonus seen for this card in recent times. The 100 XP qualifies cardholders for Flying Blue Silver status, which includes perks such as priority check-in and boarding, a free standard seat selection, 25% off seat upgrades, and an extra checked bag on SkyTeam flights. The card carries an $89 annual fee and earns 3X miles on Air France, KLM, SkyTeam purchases, and dining, plus 1.5X on all other purchases. It has no foreign transaction fees. Additional benefits include 20 XP annually, a 5,000-mile anniversary bonus for minimal spending, and ways to earn more XP through higher annual spend thresholds (up to 160 XP total possible in a year via card activity). item.title: US treasury secretary Scott Bessent calls Denmark ‘irrelevant’ at Davos
item.description: The video shows a clip from the World Economic Forum in Davos where U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent seemingly dismisses Denmark's economic significance, referring to the country as 'irrelevant.' The clip focuses on Bessent's brief comment and the reactions from others present.

item.title: Practical Design Tips for Custom Socks That Look and Feel Great
item.description:
The article explores how to design custom socks that not only look appealing but also hold up well in everyday wear. It emphasizes the importance of balancing creativity with practicality, noting that socks function as both fashion statements and wearable objects subject to stretch, motion, and structural limitations. A good sock design, according to the piece, focuses on visual clarity, durability, and adaptability to the fabric's behavior. Clear, bold patterns outperform intricate artwork, since socks are viewed mostly from a distance, and small details can disappear or distort when worn.
The text highlights several effective design approaches such as using minimal line icons, micro-patterns, and directional stripes to create visually balanced and functional results. It points out that large motifs with ample negative space or abstract color blocks can conceal distortion well, while simple botanical silhouettes and restrained typography add personality without losing legibility. item.title: U.S. Sanctions Deepen Iran's Economic Crisis but Strengthen Its Alliances with Russia and China
item.description:
During the 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent claimed that former President Trump’s 'maximum pressure' policy successfully destabilized Iran by collapsing its economy and provoking widespread protests. According to Bessent, sanctions intentionally targeted Iran’s access to global financial networks and oil revenue, cutting it off from foreign reserves. By December 2025, the Iranian rial had lost over 80% of its value, triggering inflation exceeding 40% and dramatic spikes in food prices, which fueled public unrest.
Despite this economic hardship, the article argues that the sanctions have also strengthened Iran’s determination and pushed it toward greater cooperation with adversaries of the United States. Iran has adopted methods to circumvent restrictions, such as operating a 'ghost fleet' of tankers to continue crude exports—mostly to China, which now purchases about 90% of Iranian oil at discounted prices. item.title: Historic speech (SUB) of Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney against D.Trump's Imperialism
item.description: The video features a subtitled speech by Mark Carney, former Governor of the Bank of Canada and Bank of England, where he critiques what he describes as economic policies reminiscent of imperialist practices, seemingly in reference to the policies of Donald Trump. He discusses topics like trade, globalization, and the potential negative impacts of protectionism.

item.title: ICE memo authorizes use of administrative warrants for home entries in deportation cases
item.description: An internal memo from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated May 12, 2025, has surfaced revealing that ICE officers are now authorized to forcibly enter the homes of people with final deportation orders using administrative, rather than judicial, warrants. The document, attributed to Acting Director Todd Lyons, was shared with Senator Richard Blumenthal by whistleblowers represented by Whistleblower Aid. It marks a significant shift from prior DHS policy, which traditionally required judicial warrants signed by judges for home entry. The memo cites guidance from the Department of Homeland Security’s Office of General Counsel stating that neither the Constitution nor immigration laws prohibit this practice. The directive specifies that ICE officers must identify themselves, announce their purpose, allow time for compliance, and generally avoid raids between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., using only reasonable force if necessary. item.title: Opinion: Trump's Greenland Pressure Could Prompt Iceland and Norway to Pursue EU Membership
item.description: In this opinion piece, Daniel Hegedüs argues that the Trump administration's aggressive claims and threats regarding Greenland—targeting NATO ally Denmark's territorial integrity—have disrupted Arctic security and created an opportunity for the European Union to strengthen its geopolitical position. Rather than reacting defensively, the EU should proactively use the crisis to encourage Iceland and Norway to revive their EU membership bids. In Iceland, the government has committed to a plebiscite by 2027 on resuming EU accession talks, and recent polls show a relative majority supporting membership for the first time since 2015, driven by fears of NATO unreliability under U.S. assertiveness. In Norway, support for EU accession has reached historic highs since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with a majority favoring a new referendum and the Conservative Party framing membership as a strategic security necessity amid potential transatlantic strains. item.title: Construction Begins on Bishoftu International Airport, Set to Become Africa's Largest Aviation Hub
item.description: Construction has officially started on Bishoftu International Airport (BIA), a major infrastructure project located about 40 kilometers southeast of Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa. Designed by the renowned firm Zaha Hadid Architects for Ethiopian Airlines Group, the airport aims to serve as the country's primary international gateway and position Ethiopia as a key aviation connector linking Africa with Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Upon full completion, BIA is projected to handle up to 110 million passengers per year, making it the highest-capacity airport on the African continent. The initial phase, targeted for opening around 2030, will accommodate approximately 60 million passengers annually, featuring two runways and a large terminal. The design prioritizes efficiency, passenger comfort, and cultural relevance, incorporating a central organizational spine to streamline transfers, integrated gardens, outdoor courtyards, and a 350-room airside hotel for rest amid high traffic.

item.title: Trump Comments on Needing a Dictator in Remarks Following Davos Speech Amid Greenland Tensions
item.description: President Donald Trump, speaking after his address at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland on January 21, 2026, remarked that while critics often label him a 'horrible dictator-type person,' 'sometimes you need a dictator.' He described his speech as well-received and based on common sense rather than ideology. The article highlights this as evidence of Trump's normalization of authoritarian rhetoric, set against his aggressive diplomatic stance, including threats toward Europe, Canada, Greenland, and Iceland. Trump's Davos speech focused on pushing for U.S. control of Greenland for security reasons, confusing it with Iceland at times, and threatening tariffs on European allies opposing the move. In response, the EU suspended progress on a U.S. trade deal, and pension funds in Denmark and Sweden began divesting from U.S. Treasuries due to policy unpredictability. item.title: Mark Carney Calls for 'Value-Based Realism' and Unity Among Middle Powers at Davos 2026
item.description: In his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos on January 20, 2026, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney addressed the deepening geopolitical tensions among major powers—United States, China, and Russia—and declared that the post-1945 rules-based international order is in irreversible decline. He described the current global situation as a 'rupture, not a transition,' where economic tools like tariffs and supply chains are increasingly weaponized, and major powers act with fewer constraints. Carney urged middle powers, such as Canada, to abandon complacency and adopt a 'value-based realism'—a principled yet pragmatic approach grounded in human rights, sovereignty, territorial integrity, and the prohibition of force except under the UN Charter. He criticized the tacit acceptance of inequality among nations to avoid conflict, likening it to a comfortable lie. item.title: US Completes First Sale of Venezuelan Oil Post-Maduro Capture, Transfers Funds via Qatar to Stabilize Bolívar
item.description: Following the US military capture of Nicolás Maduro in January 2026, the Trump administration has begun managing and selling Venezuelan crude oil. The first transaction generated $500 million, with $300 million routed through Qatari banks to Venezuela's interim government under Delcy Rodríguez. These funds aim to stabilize the devaluing bolívar by injecting them into the currency market. The deal stems from Trump's announced plan for Venezuela to supply 30-50 million barrels to the US at market prices (around $56 per barrel), potentially worth up to $2.8 billion, shifting from discounted sales. The US oversees the process as leverage over Venezuela's politics and economy, with plans for American companies to invest in rehabilitating the nation's oil infrastructure amid its vast reserves exceeding 300 billion barrels. Officials like Marco Rubio emphasize control for influence, while Chris Wright claims benefits for Venezuelans. Qatar serves as an intermediary for less transparent transf

item.title: Spotify and Major Labels Secure US Court Order to Suspend Anna’s Archive Domains Over Alleged Spotify Scraping
item.description: Shadow library Anna’s Archive, known for hosting pirated books and other media, recently scraped approximately 300TB of data from Spotify, including metadata, audio analysis, and cover art for millions of tracks, with plans to potentially release audio files. In late December 2025, Spotify, Sony, Warner, and Universal Music Group filed a sealed lawsuit in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York accusing the site of copyright infringement. On January 2, 2026, a judge granted an ex parte temporary restraining order directing domain registry Public Interest Registry (PIR) and Cloudflare to disable access to Anna’s Archive domains to prevent further distribution of copyrighted material. Anna’s Archive was not notified until after implementation, as plaintiffs feared preemptive release of the scraped songs or infrastructure relocation. The site’s operator initially attributed the early January .org domain suspension to routine shadow library issues unrelated to Spotify.

item.title: Common Design Errors in Enamel Pins and Practical Solutions for Better Production
item.description: Designing enamel pins seems simple due to their small size, bold shapes, and limited colors, but many designs fail in production because they ignore the physical realities of metal manufacturing. Enamel pins are not digital prints; they involve constraints like minimum line widths for metal formation, color separation requirements, plating effects, and tight tolerances. This article outlines ten frequent mistakes made by designers and provides clear fixes. item.title: Study Shows Persistent Villous Atrophy in Many Adult Celiac Patients on Long-Term Gluten-Free Diet, But Lamina Propria Immune Normalization Occurs
item.description: A recent study led by Aida Fiz López, published in Clinical and Experimental Immunology, investigated why many adult celiac disease patients continue to show intestinal mucosal damage despite years of strict gluten-free diet adherence. The research analyzed duodenal biopsies from 19 celiac patients (average 7 years on diet), compared to newly diagnosed patients and healthy controls, using advanced spectral cytometry to examine 72 immune cell populations. Results revealed that 68.4% of patients on the diet still had persistent villous atrophy. Notably, only one patient showed gluten traces in feces, confirming good dietary compliance in the others, and most had negative serology (antibodies). Despite the ongoing atrophy, the immune infiltrate in the lamina propria (including NK cells, B cells, regulatory T cells, and others altered at diagnosis) fully normalized in all diet-treated patients. item.title: Choice Privileges Launches Triple Points Promotion on Qualifying Hotel Stays Through March 31, 2026
item.description: Choice Privileges, the loyalty program of Choice Hotels, has introduced a new promotion offering triple points on qualifying stays at participating properties worldwide. The offer requires registration at the Choice Hotels website before checking in to the first eligible stay. Booking must occur between January 20, 2026, and March 30, 2026, with stays completed between January 22, 2026, and March 31, 2026 (with slight date adjustments for members from Australia and New Zealand, starting January 21 for bookings and January 23 for stays). This promotion applies to all Choice Privileges members globally, covering properties in regions such as the US, Canada, Europe, Middle East, Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Caribbean, Central and South America. However, it excludes certain countries in Europe: Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia. item.title: Building an Effective Firming Skincare Routine for Improved Skin Elasticity and Lifted Appearance
item.description: As skin loses some of its natural bounce with age, a consistent firming skincare routine can help achieve a more lifted, toned, and refreshed look without invasive procedures or overly complicated steps. Firming products primarily work on the skin's surface and upper layers by enhancing hydration, improving texture for better light reflection, and supporting elasticity, resulting in plumper, smoother, and more resilient-looking skin. The article emphasizes that true 'all-over lift' comes from better hydration to reduce crepiness, smoother texture, and gradual resilience rather than dramatic physical lifting. A simple morning routine should include a gentle cleanse, a lightweight firming serum or treatment, a hydrating moisturizer, and most importantly, daily broad-spectrum sunscreen to prevent UV damage, which accelerates loss of firmness. item.title: Capital One Shopping Rewards Limited to Southwest Rapid Rewards Points Purchases, Not Flight Bookings
item.description: Capital One Shopping, a popular browser extension and service that provides cashback rewards and coupons, has been sending targeted emails highlighting 'Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards' as an offer. This might lead users to believe they can earn rewards when booking actual Southwest flights through the portal. However, this is not the case. The rewards are only applicable when purchasing Rapid Rewards points directly, typically via Points.com, and explicitly exclude purchases of flights, hotels, cars, vacations, cruises, or gift cards. The article's author initially noticed this in emails received a couple of weeks prior to January 21, 2026, and investigated further. Unlike some other shopping portals that clearly label Southwest offers as 'Rapid Rewards – Points' or link directly to the points purchase page, Capital One Shopping lists it ambiguously as 'Southwest Rapid Rewards' and links to the main Rapid Rewards section of Southwest's site, creating potential confusion. item.title: Evaluating the Real Value of the $795 Chase Sapphire Reserve Card
item.description:
The article by Greg from Frequent Miler analyzes whether it is worthwhile to keep the Chase Sapphire Reserve® card after the recent overhaul and increase in its annual fee from $550 to $795. The card, once celebrated for its simplicity and generous travel perks, now offers a wide array of complicated credits and coupons. Greg explains that determining the card’s value depends on how effectively a cardholder uses those benefits, particularly new additions such as The Edit travel credits, StubHub rebates, Lyft and DoorDash credits, and entertainment subscriptions like Apple TV+ and Apple Music.
To assess whether the card is worth keeping, Greg introduces a personal evaluation method using his 'bundling' approach. Instead of pricing each coupon individually, he groups related benefits—like travel perks or miscellaneous lifestyle credits—and estimates how much he would realistically pay for those bundles. item.title: Oxfam Reports Record Surge in Billionaire Wealth to $18.3 Trillion in 2025, Linked to Rising Political Influence and Global Inequality
item.description: According to a new Oxfam report released on January 19, 2026, coinciding with the World Economic Forum in Davos, billionaire wealth surged by more than 16% in 2025—three times faster than the average growth over the previous five years—reaching a historic high of $18.3 trillion. This represents an 81% increase since 2020. The collective wealth grew by $2.5 trillion in 2025 alone, nearly matching the total wealth of the bottom half of humanity (4.1 billion people) and enough to eradicate extreme poverty 26 times over. The number of billionaires exceeded 3,000 for the first time, with Elon Musk becoming the first to surpass half a trillion dollars. The report, titled 'Resisting the Rule of the Rich: Protecting Freedom from Billionaire Power,' highlights how this extreme wealth concentration enables the super-rich to gain disproportionate political power, including through tax cuts for the wealthy, weakened corporate regulations, and media ownership. item.title: Vintage Covers of Flying Magazine from the 1950s
item.description: Flying magazine, first published in 1927, stands as the world's most widely read aviation publication and a key resource for pilots and aviation enthusiasts. Over nearly a century, it has documented the progression of flight technology, from early propeller-driven aircraft to modern jets, business aviation, and emerging electric aircraft innovations. The magazine is particularly noted for its detailed 'Pilot Reports,' in which experienced aviators offer thorough evaluations of new aircraft models, along with expert columns on critical topics such as flight safety, navigation techniques, and weather interpretation. In addition to technical content, Flying magazine highlights the emotional and experiential aspects of flying through stunning aerial photography and narrative pieces that emphasize the sense of freedom and adventure in the skies. item.title: Systematic Review Highlights Potential Health Benefits and Sustainability of Bamboo Shoots as an Underutilized Food Source
item.description: Bamboo shoots, long a staple in Asian cuisines through stir-fries, soups, and fermented preparations, are gaining scientific attention as a potentially nutrient-dense food. A recent systematic review published in Advances in Bamboo Science analyzed decades of research, including human trials, animal studies, and lab work, on bamboo shoots and derived compounds. Key findings indicate that bamboo shoots are rich in dietary fiber, such as cellulose and lignin, which supports digestion, gut health, regularity, and possibly beneficial gut bacteria. Early human studies suggest benefits for metabolic health, including better blood sugar regulation and improved cholesterol levels, which could lower risks for diabetes and heart disease. Lab research reveals antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that may reduce cellular stress and chronic inflammation. item.description: IHG Business Rewards, a program for business travelers and planners integrated with IHG One Rewards, is running a promotion where members can earn double points on qualifying spend for stays, meetings, conferences, and events booked for others. To participate, users must be enrolled in IHG Business Rewards and register for the offer. Bookings made between October 1, 2025, and March 4, 2026, that are completed by August 31, 2026, qualify for 2x points—equating to a total of 6 points per $1 USD spent (3 base points plus 3 bonus points). item.description: A targeted American Express Offer has been issued for select cardholders, providing a $50 statement credit when spending $250 or more on eligible Alamo Rent-a-Car transactions. The offer, which appeared last week and was highlighted on January 21, 2026, requires users to first add it to their eligible Amex card via the offers section. item.title: Anti-Trump Protests in Zurich Escalate with Flag Burnings and Clashes Ahead of Davos WEF Attendance Amid Greenland Dispute
item.description: Protesters in Zurich, Switzerland, demonstrated strongly against US President Donald Trump's upcoming appearance at the World Economic Forum in Davos, burning American flags and carrying signs such as 'Trump not welcome' and 'Put the Trumpster in the dumpster.' The unrest, which involved thousands of participants, turned violent with reports of smashed windows, property damage, and clashes with police. Authorities deployed riot gear, water cannons, chemical irritants, and rubber bullets after protesters allegedly threw stones and fireworks; no injuries were reported. The protests were fueled by Trump's persistent threats to acquire Greenland from Denmark for US security reasons, including refusing to rule out military action and proposing tariffs on European countries supporting Denmark. In response, European leaders like Ursula von der Leyen criticized the tariff threats and asserted Europe's role in Arctic security. item.title: Satirical Post Claims Greenland Protesters Are Paid to Reject U.S. Statehood Offer
item.description: In a January 19, 2026, post on his Substack, the self-styled 'Representative Jack Kimble' expresses strong frustration with protesters in Greenland who are opposing the idea of the territory becoming the 51st U.S. state. He claims that the people of Greenland, described derogatorily as living on a 'desolate ice ball,' are being paid to reject a supposed generous American offer of $100,000 per person. Kimble argues that no one would turn down such a large sum out of pure principle, implying the protests lack authenticity. item.description: According to the Spanish Tribunal de Cuentas' 2025 report on political party transparency and the PCE's own annual financial disclosures from 2017 to 2023, the Partido Comunista de España (PCE) has faced persistent financial challenges. item.title: The Historical Survival of San Marino: From a Legend to a Modern Republic
item.description: The article explores the origins and historical endurance of San Marino, recognized as the world's oldest republic. According to legend, San Marino was founded in 301 CE by Marinus, a Dalmatian stonemason who fled persecution under Emperor Diocletian and established a hermitage on Mount Titano. Although modern historians see this as likely myth, a real monastic community existed there by the mid-8th century, gradually evolving into an autonomous republic. By the 13th century, San Marino had developed its unique system of government led by two 'Captains Regent', a diarchy that still operates today. Throughout history, San Marino's survival depended on diplomacy and prudence rather than military might. The republic avoided absorption into surrounding territories by maintaining good relations with the Papacy, Napoleon, and later the Kingdom of Italy. item.description: This article by Dr. Steve Benner explores how Roman emperors and officials frequently featured monumental architecture on their coinage to commemorate constructions they sponsored or to promote their legacy. Many structures, such as temples, markets, arches, and other edifices, are depicted in detail on coins from the Republic through the Imperial period, providing valuable visual evidence since most no longer stand. item.description: A recent academic study highlights that the 2020 pandemic lockdowns caused lasting disruptions in the educational and professional trajectories of young students. The negative impact was more pronounced in regions with stricter lockdowns, suggesting a link to mental health challenges. item.description: On January 17, 2026, China's space program suffered a rare setback with two launch failures occurring within less than 24 hours, marking the first major issues after a perfect record of 69 Long March launches plus four Jielong-3 missions in 2025. A problem with the cryogenic third stage, powered by YF-75 engines, resulted in the complete loss of the mission, preventing the satellite from reaching its intended orbit. This was notable as the CZ-3B family, a veteran launcher from CALT with 175 missions since 1984, had only experienced four prior failures (one total in 1996, and others partial or total mostly tied to the third stage). item.title: CAS Space Conducts First Successful Flight of Suborbital Rocket Lihong 1
item.description: On January 12, 2026, CAS Space successfully conducted the maiden flight of its suborbital rocket, Lihong 1, from the Dongfeng commercial space site at the Jiuquan Space Center. The rocket carried a capsule containing microgravity experiments, including rose seeds, which reached an apogee of approximately 120 kilometers, crossing the Kármán line into space. The capsule separated from the rocket 104 seconds after launch at around 75 kilometers in altitude, deployed a parachute at roughly 70 kilometers, and landed 170 kilometers west of the launch site. The mission provided about five minutes of microgravity for the experiments. The Lihong 1 is a single-stage, solid-fuel rocket with a launch mass of 7 tons and a thrust of 156 kilonewtons, capable of reaching up to 200 kilometers. item.title: Spain’s pragmatic migration policy supports its economy and workforce needs
item.description:
Spain stands out in Europe for promoting a positive and pragmatic narrative on migration at a time when many countries are tightening immigration policies. The Spanish government openly argues that migrants are essential to sustaining its economy, compensating for an ageing population, and filling gaps in key labour-intensive sectors such as hospitality, construction, and agriculture. Between 2002 and 2024, 75% of the 5.2 million new workers entering Spain’s labour market were foreign nationals or dual citizens.
Over the past two decades, Spain has focused on integrating migrants through flexible regularisation mechanisms rather than punitive approaches. It offers various legalisation pathways based on work, education, family, and social ties, while easing access to residency and work permits. She highlighted the ongoing collaborative work between Ukraine, the United States, and European supporters to develop peace plans, including robust security guarantees for Kyiv. item.title: Global Poll Shows Trump's Policies Boosting Perceptions of China's Influence Over the US
item.description: A recent global survey conducted by the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) in November 2025, involving 25,949 respondents from 21 countries, reveals a significant shift in international perceptions of global power dynamics one year into President Donald Trump's second term. The poll indicates that many people worldwide now view China as the rising power, with majorities in countries such as the United States (54%), the European Union (53%), India (51%), and Brazil (72%) expecting China to exert greater global influence in the coming decade. In contrast, fewer respondents anticipate the United States gaining more influence, and perceptions of the US as a reliable ally have declined in several nations, including the UK (25%) and EU countries (16%). The survey attributes this shift to Trump's 'America First' policies, including high tariffs on allies and adversaries, skepticism toward traditional alliances, and tensions with partners like Ukraine and European nations. item.title: EU proposes mutual visa-free work and residence scheme with Australia
item.description: The European Union is considering a groundbreaking agreement with Australia that could allow citizens of both regions to live and work freely across each other’s territories. This initiative, part of renewed efforts to complete a long-delayed free trade agreement (FTA), aims to introduce a two-way labour mobility scheme between Australia and the EU’s 27 member states. Under the proposed plan, Australians would be able to live and work in European countries such as France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, and Spain for up to four years without needing to secure a job in advance. In return, EU citizens would be granted similar rights to live and work in Australia. The scheme seeks to ease labour shortages on both sides while fostering stronger social and economic ties. If approved, it would replace existing working holiday visa agreements that currently restrict how long Australians can reside and work in Europe and potentially open the door to more permanent settlement options.

The attacks, allegedly orchestrated by a structured group of state-affiliated hackers, targeted Microsoft Exchange servers and affected tens of thousands of organizations worldwide. Victims included research laboratories involved in COVID-19 vaccine development, government institutions, and major companies in countries such as France and the United States. item.title: The History and Cultural Impact of the Bullet Bra in Mid-20th Century Fashion
item.description: During the late 1940s and 1950s, women’s fashion emphasized structure, shape, and highly stylized silhouettes, with undergarments serving as essential tools for achieving the desired body form. The bullet bra emerged as one of the most iconic and visually striking garments of this period. Designed with stiff, conical cups reinforced with spiral stitching, it projected the bust sharply outward, creating a dramatic hourglass figure. The style reflected post-World War II societal expectations, where women were encouraged to embrace traditional femininity after participating in industrial and military roles during the war. Advertisements often used military terminology, such as 'bullet' and 'torpedo,' to highlight precision and projection. Hollywood and popular media helped normalize the pointed silhouette through pin-up models and actresses, giving rise to the famous 'sweater girl' look. item.title: The Unique Appeal of Water-Based Outdoor Travel: Lakes, Rivers, and Coasts
item.description: Traveling by water offers a distinct and immersive way to experience the outdoors, differing from road-based journeys by emphasizing a slower, more deliberate pace shaped by natural elements like wind, light, currents, and tides. Rather than following straight paths, water routes allow access to hidden inlets, quiet coves, and remote shorelines that roads cannot reach, fostering a deeper connection to the landscape. The article explores three main types of water travel: lakes, which provide a grounding, circular exploration with opportunities for anchoring, swimming, and enjoying serene, mirrored sunsets amid pine-lined shores; rivers, which create a narrative of continuous motion with ever-changing bends, wildlife corridors, and earned progress measured by flow rather than distance; and coasts, which involve an outward sense of adventure with open horizons, variable weather, harbor hops, and awareness of tides and swells. item.title: The Role of Brothels in Imperial Rome: A Source of Information, Corruption, and Political Control
item.description: In ancient Rome, brothels were not merely places of vice but integral to the empire's social and political fabric. Far from being accidental, they were tolerated, regulated, and monitored by the state. The Lupanar in Pompeii, with its explicit frescoes and graffiti, reveals everyday life, including prices, boasts, insults, and even political comments, where soldiers, officials, and slaves mingled anonymously. The Subura neighborhood in Rome mixed senators, prostitutes, and politicians, serving as an unfiltered source of rumors about debts, bribes, and shifting allegiances—close enough to the Forum to function as a political barometer. Prostitution was legalized and taxed; women had to register with authorities, obtaining a 'licentia stupri,' and records were sometimes used for political leverage by emperors. item.title: The Torment of Saint Anthony: Michelangelo's Earliest Known Painting at Age 12-13 Confirmed at Kimbell Art Museum
item.description:
The article explores *The Torment of Saint Anthony*, widely regarded as Michelangelo Buonarroti's first painting, created around 1487–1488 when he was just 12 or 13 years old. This small tempera and oil on panel work depicts Saint Anthony the Great levitating and tormented by demons, based closely on a 15th-century engraving by Martin Schongauer. Michelangelo enhanced the original with realistic details, such as fish scales on demons studied from a market, a added landscape resembling the Arno Valley, and compositional refinements for greater impact.
For centuries, its attribution to Michelangelo was debated, as he primarily identified as a sculptor and disparaged oil painting later in life. The painting sold at Sotheby's in 2008, initially under a workshop attribution. item.description: A recent report indicates a concerning trend: the U.S.-born unemployment rate has increased following immigration restrictions implemented under the Trump administration. item.title: Art and Propaganda in the Postcards of the Russo-Japanese War (1904–1905)
item.description:
The article explores the visually striking and historically significant postcards produced during the Russo-Japanese War of 1904–1905, a conflict between Imperial Japan and Tsarist Russia that marked a turning point in East Asian and global power dynamics. On February 8, 1904, Japan launched a surprise attack on the Russian naval base at Port Arthur, triggering a war that left hundreds of thousands dead before ending with Japan’s victory in 1905. This triumph positioned Japan as the first modern Asian power to defeat a European empire and influenced both nations’ subsequent political and social developments.
The piece highlights how millions of postcards depicting key events—naval battles, national personifications, and satirical scenes—became powerful tools of wartime communication and propaganda. It highlights the critical role of high-quality photographs, advising sellers to capture images at optimal times with natural light, clear angles, decluttered spaces, and attention to details like clean surfaces and open storage areas to make rooms appear more spacious and inviting. Staging tips focus on creating calm, intentional vignettes using gallery walls, minimal decorative objects, and neutral elements to let buyers envision themselves in the space. A key recommendation is assembling a 'proof pack' containing summaries of home updates, permits, utility costs, and required disclosures—especially relevant under Minnesota statutes—to preempt buyer questions, reduce back-and-forth, and build trust for faster decisions. The piece also suggests structured showing windows, use of lockboxes for convenience, pet reloc

item.title: La Razón elogia el atuendo de Ayuso durante un minuto de silencio por las víctimas de Adamuz
item.description: La noticia denuncia la práctica de algunos medios de comunicación, específicamente 'La Razón', de ensalzar la imagen de la presidenta de la Comunidad de Madrid, Isabel Díaz Ayuso, con un enfoque similar al de los artículos de 'lifestyle' de revistas de celebridades. El caso más reciente es la publicación de un artículo destacando su atuendo durante el minuto de silencio por las víctimas de la tragedia de Adamuz. La publicación no solo describe el diseño de la ropa, sino que utiliza adjetivos como 'seriedad', 'equilibrio' y 'imagen pulida', generando controversia y críticas en redes sociales, donde usuarios se cuestionan la falta de respeto y la banalización de un momento de duelo nacional. Esta práctica, según la noticia, se ha convertido en una constante, donde la figura de Ayuso es tratada con una deferencia que contrasta con su discurso público, donde ha criticado duramente al gobierno. El artículo critica la continua búsqueda de 'lamebotas' para la presidenta, elevándola a un nivel

item.title: Científicos españoles desarrollan método para anticipar erupciones volcánicas hasta 48 horas antes
item.description: Un equipo de investigadores españoles del IGME-CSIC, el Instituto Geográfico Nacional y la Universidad de Valencia ha desarrollado una metodología innovadora capaz de predecir erupciones volcánicas con hasta 48 horas de antelación. Publicado en 'Scientific Reports', este avance permite detectar cambios en los patrones sísmicos del magma, lo que indica que se ha iniciado su ascenso hacia la superficie. Según los científicos, el magma sigue una 'memoria' que permanece estable mientras se encuentra estancado; cuando se produce un cambio en esa sismicidad, la erupción es inminente. Este sistema no solo avisa del inicio de la erupción, sino que también puede identificar cuándo el volcán comienza a perder fuerza, facilitando la planificación del retorno de la población evacuada y la reconstrucción de las zonas afectadas. La erupción del volcán Tajogaite en La Palma en 2021 sirvió como base para desarrollar el modelo, gracias a la recopilación de datos hora a hora durante los 86 días de activ

item.title: Ucrania utiliza drones aéreos para transportar y desplegar robots terrestres de combate cerca del frente
item.description:
La guerra en Ucrania ha evolucionado rápidamente hacia un modelo donde drones y robots protagonizan el combate, reduciendo al mínimo la exposición de soldados humanos. Una táctica reciente y sorprendente consiste en emplear drones aéreos grandes como medio de transporte improvisado para llevar robots terrestres (UGV) pequeños hasta posiciones cercanas al enemigo, soltándolos en el lugar idóneo. De este modo se evitan los trayectos terrestres más peligrosos, plagados de minas, artillería, barro y detección enemiga, que causan numerosas bajas.
Esta innovación, descrita por mandos ucranianos y confirmada por la empresa Ark Robotics (que suministra robots a más de 20 brigadas), ha sorprendido incluso a sus propios fabricantes. El CEO de Ark, bajo seudónimo por seguridad, reconoció que la idea es simple pero extremadamente lógica: los drones aéreos superan con rapidez zonas de alto riesgo, mientras que los robots terrestres destacan una vez desplegados, ya que pueden infiltrarse en trinche

item.title: El Gobierno español propone acabar con el anonimato en redes sociales para reforzar la responsabilidad online
item.description: El primer ministro de España ha expresado su intención de eliminar las cuentas anónimas en las redes sociales, argumentando que esta medida contribuiría a reducir el acoso, las amenazas y la difusión de desinformación en línea. Según su propuesta, todas las plataformas deberían implementar mecanismos de verificación de identidad que vinculen las cuentas a personas reales, con el objetivo de aumentar la responsabilidad de los usuarios. La iniciativa ha generado un debate intenso sobre privacidad, libertad de expresión y seguridad digital. Mientras algunos apoyan la medida por considerar que podría disminuir los comportamientos abusivos y proteger a víctimas de ciberacoso, otros critican que podría limitar el anonimato necesario para denunciar injusticias o proteger la identidad de activistas y periodistas. El debate también incluye consideraciones técnicas y legales, ya que implementar un sistema de verificación de identidad universal plantea retos de seguridad, protección de datos y po

item.title: ‘Pasión’, la farsa trágica de Agustín García Calvo como crítica radical a la sociedad contemporánea
item.description:
La noticia ofrece una reseña detallada de la obra teatral *Pasión*, definida por su autor, Agustín García Calvo, como una farsa trágica en la que el deporte actúa únicamente como pretexto para una crítica mucho más profunda. A través del personaje de Enrique, elevado a héroe por una sociedad hedonista y decadente, la obra retrata el ascenso y la caída de unos valores colectivos basados en la competición, la idolatría y la obediencia acrítica. El deporte aparece simbolizado como una “cucaña” que promete éxito y gloria, pero que acaba revelando el vacío moral y humano que sostiene ese ideal.
La reseña subraya el carácter despiadado de la crítica social que recorre toda la pieza. García Calvo ridiculiza las pasiones de un pueblo entendido como masa, capaz de emocionarse con gestas deportivas mientras acepta sin cuestionamiento una estructura social grotesca, estatista y deshumanizada. En este contexto destaca la figura del “Padredelpueblo”, un personaje esperpéntico que encarna el adoctr

item.title: Víctima de Jeffrey Epstein denuncia ante tribunal la demora del Departamento de Justicia en publicar los archivos completos del caso
item.description:
Una de las sobrevivientes de la red de explotación sexual de Jeffrey Epstein, Haley Robson, ha enviado una carta a un tribunal del distrito sureste de Nueva York en la que critica duramente al Departamento de Justicia de Estados Unidos por no haber publicado de forma íntegra los archivos relacionados con el caso, tal como obliga la ley aprobada por el Congreso y firmada por el presidente Donald Trump a finales de 2025 (Epstein Files Transparency Act). En la misiva, Robson califica esta omisión como un «secretismo» que no es solo un problema burocrático, sino algo profundamente personal para las víctimas, ya que perpetúa el mismo encubrimiento que permitió que los abusos continuaran durante años sin ser controlados. Además, subraya que la demora envía un mensaje doloroso: que la justicia no alcanza a las personas ricas y poderosas implicadas en los crímenes.
El Departamento de Justicia respondió la semana anterior afirmando que está avanzando en la revisión de un volumen muy elevado de

item.title: En Dinamarca se disparan las descargas de apps para identificar y evitar productos estadounidenses por las declaraciones de Trump sobre Groenlandia
item.description:
En Dinamarca, las aplicaciones móviles NonUSA y Made O'Meter han experimentado un crecimiento explosivo en descargas durante la última semana de enero de 2026, con un aumento promedio del 867 % según datos de Appfigures y reportes de TechCrunch. NonUSA ha alcanzado el primer puesto en la App Store danesa, tras partir del puesto 441. Estas herramientas permiten escanear códigos de barras o fotos de productos para determinar su país de origen, alertando si son fabricados en Estados Unidos y sugiriendo alternativas locales o europeas.
El fenómeno responde directamente a las repetidas declaraciones del presidente Donald Trump sobre la posible adquisición o mayor control estadounidense de Groenlandia, territorio autónomo bajo soberanía danesa. Estas afirmaciones han generado indignación en Dinamarca y Groenlandia, provocando protestas masivas en Copenhague y otras ciudades europeas con lemas como 'Greenland is not for sale' o 'Make America Go Away'. item.title: Donald Trump presenta una demanda contra JP Morgan y Jamie Dimon por 5.000 millones de dólares alegando desbancarización por motivos políticos
item.description: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ha presentado una demanda contra JP Morgan Chase, el mayor banco del país, y su consejero delegado, Jamie Dimon, por un importe de al menos 5.000 millones de dólares (unos 4.300 millones de euros). La acusación principal es que el banco canceló unilateralmente varias cuentas bancarias de Trump por motivos políticos, tras el asalto al Capitolio del 6 de enero de 2021, cuando Trump alentó a sus seguidores a impedir la certificación de la victoria electoral de Joe Biden. La demanda, interpuesta en un tribunal estatal del condado de Miami-Dade (Florida), alega violación de los códigos éticos del banco, difamación comercial, incumplimiento del pacto de buena fe y trato justo, así como infracción de la Ley de Prácticas Comerciales Desleales y Engañosas de Florida. Trump argumenta que la decisión de JP Morgan fue motivada por presiones políticas y sociales progresistas para distanciarse de sus opiniones conservadoras. El banco ha respondido afirm

item.title: Trump cuestiona encuestas desfavorables tras registrar su menor aprobación
item.description: El presidente Donald Trump ha reaccionado con fuerza a los últimos sondeos que muestran su índice de aprobación más bajo desde que asumió su segundo mandato. A través de varias publicaciones en Truth Social, Trump acusó a grandes medios de comunicación y empresas de encuestas de publicar resultados sesgados para perjudicar su presidencia. En concreto, criticó la encuesta conjunta del New York Times y el Siena College Research Institute, afirmando que estaba inclinada a favor de los demócratas y anunciando acciones legales para exigir que se conserven los registros internos de la encuesta. Según estas encuestas recientes, su aprobación se encuentra en torno al 35-40%, con un desaprobación superior al 60%, reflejando un debilitamiento notable incluso en áreas donde Trump solía mostrar fortaleza, como economía, inmigración y seguridad fronteriza. Trump argumenta que existen encuestas favorables a su gestión que no se publican y que los medios utilizan los sondeos como herramienta política

item.title: Maria Machado propone intervenciones militares en Cuba y Nicaragua tras el caso de Venezuela, desatando críticas en redes
item.description: Maria Corina Machado, galardonada con el Premio Nobel de la Paz en 2025 y líder de la oposición venezolana, ha generado una fuerte polémica tras declarar públicamente que Estados Unidos debería intervenir militarmente en Cuba y Nicaragua de forma similar a la reciente operación en Venezuela, donde se capturó al presidente Nicolás Maduro y su esposa. Durante su visita a Washington y reuniones con legisladores estadounidenses, Machado defendió que la liberación de Venezuela era solo el primer paso hacia la eliminación del comunismo y la dictadura en América Latina. Sus comentarios provocaron críticas inmediatas en redes sociales, donde muchos usuarios la calificaron de hipócrita y cuestionaron su idoneidad para recibir el Nobel de la Paz. Algunos la acusaron de fomentar el belicismo y de confundir la libertad con la justificación de intervenciones militares. Este episodio se produce después de que Machado entregara su medalla del Nobel al expresidente estadounidense Donald Trump como mue

item.title: El Ministerio traslada a Fiscalía posibles irregularidades en las oposiciones de la Seguridad Social celebradas en A Coruña
item.description: El Ministerio de Inclusión, Seguridad Social y Migraciones ha remitido a la Fiscalía Provincial de A Coruña las presuntas irregularidades detectadas en las oposiciones al Cuerpo Administrativo de la Administración de la Seguridad Social, que tuvieron lugar el 13 de septiembre de 2025 en A Coruña. Tras las denuncias de varios opositores, que alertaron de un número excepcionalmente alto de notas sobresalientes pese a la dificultad percibida de las pruebas, el Ministerio inició una investigación interna que incluyó entrevistas, análisis de documentación y revisión de procedimientos. Como resultado, se constataron indicios de hechos que podrían constituir varios delitos, lo que motivó el traslado del caso a la Fiscalía y a la Policía Judicial para una investigación más exhaustiva con los medios adecuados. Las sospechas apuntan principalmente a posibles filtraciones del examen, ya que el elevado número de aprobados y sobresalientes en la sede gallega no se corresponde con los resultados hab

item.title: Milei defiende el comercio con China y Estados Unidos y reafirma su apuesta por una economía abierta
item.description:
El presidente argentino, Javier Milei, defendió en el Foro Económico Mundial de Davos la necesidad de mantener y profundizar las relaciones comerciales de Argentina con China, a la que calificó como un “gran socio comercial”, al tiempo que reiteró su alineamiento político con Estados Unidos y su respaldo al libre comercio. En una entrevista con el editor jefe de Bloomberg News, Milei subrayó que el peso de China en la economía global hace inevitable el comercio con Pekín, incluso mientras su Gobierno busca avanzar hacia un acuerdo de libre comercio con Washington.
Las declaraciones se produjeron minutos después de que Milei participara en un evento junto al presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, reforzando la imagen de equilibrio que intenta proyectar entre ambas potencias. Aunque durante la campaña electoral había mantenido una retórica muy crítica hacia el Gobierno chino, ya como presidente ha moderado su discurso y adoptado una posición pragmática, evitando tanto un alineamiento

item.title: Legisladores republicanos celebran un acto simbólico sobre Groenlandia en un evento que impulsa un tercer mandato de Trump
item.description:
Un evento celebrado en Washington D. C. ha generado controversia internacional tras la aparición de un pastel con forma de Groenlandia decorado con la bandera de Estados Unidos. El acto tuvo lugar en el Kennedy Center durante una fiesta organizada por Republicans for National Renewal, un grupo de derecha que promueve la posibilidad de que Donald Trump aspire a un tercer mandato presidencial, algo que actualmente sería inconstitucional. El pastel fue presentado de forma irónica como el “estado número 51”, en clara alusión a la reiterada propuesta de Trump de adquirir la isla ártica.
Al encuentro asistieron varios legisladores republicanos, entre ellos Anna Paulina Luna, Abe Hamadeh y Andy Ogles. Luna fue quien cortó la primera porción del pastel, mientras algunos asistentes advertían en tono jocoso de que el gesto podía provocar un escándalo internacional. Durante la velada, Ogles recibió un reconocimiento por una enmienda que permitiría a Trump, de 79 años, presentarse a un tercer man

item.title: Macron anuncia que los ahorros europeos que se destinan a Estados Unidos se invertirán en Europa y los 27 estados acuerdan crear la Unión S&I
item.description: El presidente de Francia, Emmanuel Macron, ha declarado que los 300.000 millones de euros en ahorros de los europeos que actualmente se destinan cada año a Estados Unidos serán invertidos en Europa a partir de ahora. Esta medida se enmarca en un acuerdo alcanzado por los 27 estados miembros de la Unión Europea para establecer la Unión S&I (Sostenibilidad e Inversión), un paso importante hacia la creación de un Mercado de Capitales único y más robusto en el continente. La idea es evitar que los flujos financieros salgan de la región y fortalecer la economía interna europea. El acuerdo tiene como objetivo fomentar el crecimiento y la inversión en sectores clave como la tecnología, la sostenibilidad y las infraestructuras, promoviendo un entorno más estable y atractivo para los inversores. La creación de la Unión S&I también es vista como una respuesta a la creciente competencia de otros mercados globales y una estrategia para hacer frente a los desafíos económicos que enfrenta la Unión E

item.title: La red de alta velocidad española enfrenta problemas estructurales tras el accidente de Adamuz
item.description: El artículo analiza las posibles causas del reciente accidente ferroviario ocurrido en el tramo de vía cercano a Adamuz (Córdoba), donde un tren descarriló, probablemente por un fallo en una soldadura del raíl o un defecto en el material del acero, lo que provocó un colapso repentino sin signos evidentes de fatiga previa ni influencia térmica significativa, dado el clima suave de la zona en esa época del año. El autor descarta excusas indulgentes y apunta a una ejecución deficiente de la soldadura o problemas en el proceso de laminado del raíl. Sin embargo, enfatiza que este incidente no es aislado, sino que revela un problema más profundo y estructural en la red de alta velocidad española. Las vías, diseñadas originalmente para cargas y tráfico menores, están soportando actualmente un volumen muy superior al previsto, agravado por trenes pesados como el Frecciarossa (modelo ETR 1000 operado por Iryo), que contribuyen a un desgaste acelerado. item.title: El movimiento de solidaridad con la huelga de Minneapolis contra ICE se extiende a más de 100 ciudades en EE.UU.
item.description: Payday Report está siguiendo de cerca el creciente movimiento de huelgas y acciones de solidaridad en todo Estados Unidos en respuesta a la ocupación de ICE en Minneapolis. Según su mapa interactivo, ya hay acciones programadas en al menos 120 ciudades del país para apoyar la huelga general convocada en Minnesota. Esta movilización surge tras el llamamiento de la Minneapolis Regional Labor Federation, la Minnesota AFL-CIO y otras federaciones sindicales importantes del estado, que han declarado el viernes como 'Día de la Verdad y la Libertad'. Los trabajadores planean parar y salir a la calle en protesta. Keiran Knutson, presidente de CWA Local 7520 y uno de los líderes del movimiento, estima que decenas de miles de personas participarán en las calles de las Twin Cities. El movimiento inspira a grupos laborales, comunitarios y de derechos de inmigrantes en todo el país, y Payday Report ya había registrado acciones de solidaridad en al menos 80 ciudades. item.title: El implante subretiniano PRIMA restaura parcialmente la visión central en pacientes con atrofia geográfica por DMAE en ensayo clínico
item.description: Un estudio publicado en The New England Journal of Medicine presenta resultados de un ensayo clínico con el sistema PRIMA, un implante fotovoltaico subretiniano diseñado para restaurar la visión central en personas con atrofia geográfica avanzada, una forma grave de degeneración macular asociada a la edad (DMAE) que afecta a millones de personas en el mundo y causa pérdida irreversible de la visión detallada, lectura o reconocimiento de rostros. El dispositivo consiste en un pequeño chip implantado bajo la retina dañada y unas gafas que capturan imágenes del entorno y proyectan luz infrarroja al implante. Este convierte la luz en señales eléctricas que estimulan las células nerviosas restantes, enviando información visual al cerebro por una vía alternativa. El ensayo incluyó a 38 participantes con pérdida severa de visión central. item.title: Robert Reich plantea estrategias para frenar el régimen de Trump en 2026
item.description:
En su artículo publicado el 22 de enero de 2026, Robert Reich expresa una profunda preocupación por lo que describe como una fase especialmente peligrosa y violenta del gobierno de Trump, al que califica de régimen fascista. Destaca como ejemplo reciente el caso en el que agentes de ICE habrían utilizado a un niño de 5 años como 'cebo' para detener a sus padres, que se encontraban legalmente en Estados Unidos; tanto el menor como su padre están ahora en un centro de detención en Texas, sin que se conozca su ubicación exacta. Reich considera que estas acciones se realizan en nombre de la ciudadanía estadounidense, con sus impuestos y, aparentemente, con su pasividad.
El autor consulta a seguidores y contactos en la resistencia sobre las mejores formas de detener esta situación y presenta tres estrategias principales revisadas: 1) Presionar a un pequeño número de senadores y representantes republicanos en distritos o estados competidos para que cambien de partido o se conviertan en inde

item.title: Julio Iglesias publica conversaciones de WhatsApp de sus exempleadas para defenderse de acusaciones de agresión sexual: posibles implicaciones legales
item.description:
El cantante Julio Iglesias ha optado por una estrategia pública de defensa tras ser acusado de agresión sexual por dos exempleadas que trabajaron en sus residencias en el Caribe. Ante la negativa de la Fiscalía a incorporar como prueba mensajes de WhatsApp que, según él, desmienten las acusaciones, ha decidido publicar capturas de dichas conversaciones en su cuenta de Instagram. El objetivo es demostrar la supuesta falsedad de las denuncias y mostrar una relación cordial con las exempleadas durante y después de su empleo.
Sin embargo, esta acción podría acarrearle consecuencias legales. La Constitución Española protege el secreto de las comunicaciones (artículo 18), y el artículo 197 del Código Penal tipifica como delito la revelación de secretos o la vulneración de la intimidad sin consentimiento, especialmente si afecta al honor, la reputación o la imagen, con penas que pueden incluir prisión de tres meses a un año o multas. item.title: Declaraciones del exsecretario de Presidencia sobre la gestión de la dana del 29 de octubre de 2024
item.description: El exsecretario autonómico de Presidencia, Cayetano García Ramírez, actualmente secretario autonómico de Economía, ha comparecido ante la jueza que investiga la dana del 29 de octubre de 2024. García Ramírez declaró que la entonces consellera y mando único de la emergencia, Salomé Pradas, le comunicó su intención de reventar una presa y confinar toda la provincia, ante lo que él le aconsejó consultar a la Abogacía de la Generalitat debido a que tal decisión podría afectar derechos fundamentales. Según García Ramírez, desconocía por qué fue llamado para esa consulta, ya que es economista y no experto en derecho. Las conversaciones con Pradas retrasaron el envío del Es Alert, que había sido presentado previamente en el Cecopi. Durante la jornada de la dana, García Ramírez trasladó al jefe de gabinete de Carlos Mazón, José Manuel Cuenca, a Xàtiva y desde el Palau se dedicó a elaborar un decreto de ayudas para los afectados por el desbordamiento del río Magro en Utiel. item.title: La alcaldesa de Kujalleq rechaza presiones de Trump y defiende la soberanía sobre los minerales estratégicos de Groenlandia
item.description: La alcaldesa de Kujalleq, Malene Vahl Rasmussen, ha enviado una carta abierta al presidente Donald Trump en la que rechaza de forma contundente cualquier presión o falta de respeto hacia Groenlandia y su población. Kujalleq, el municipio más pequeño de la isla con poco más de 6000 habitantes, destaca por albergar el subsuelo con mayor concentración de minerales estratégicos y tierras raras de todo Groenlandia, recursos clave en el contexto geopolítico actual. La mandataria subraya que el subsuelo groenlandés no se vende ante retórica despectiva ni presiones políticas, y que sin confianza no habrá acceso a ni un solo gramo de estos materiales. Expresa la inquietud de los habitantes ante las declaraciones de Trump sobre querer 'acceso ilimitado' a la isla, a pesar de que el secretario general de la OTAN haya negado conversaciones específicas sobre explotación minera. La alcaldesa recuerda que Groenlandia cuenta desde 2009 con leyes propias de autonomía que protegen estrictamente sus recu

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez mantuvo contactos secretos con Estados Unidos antes del intento de captura de Maduro
item.description: Antes del intento de secuestro del presidente venezolano Nicolás Maduro a principios de enero de 2026, la vicepresidenta Delcy Rodríguez y su hermano Jorge, presidente de la Asamblea Nacional, habrían entablado conversaciones secretas con funcionarios estadounidenses y cataríes para garantizar su cooperación en caso de que Maduro dejara el poder. Según cuatro fuentes citadas por The Guardian, estas negociaciones comenzaron en otoño de 2025, tras una conversación entre Trump y Maduro en noviembre, en la que el presidente estadounidense exigió la salida de Maduro, que fue rechazada. Delcy Rodríguez habría asegurado a los estadounidenses estar dispuesta a asumir las consecuencias y colaborar con la transición, aunque sin actuar activamente para derrocar a Maduro. La familia Rodríguez mantuvo además vínculos con Qatar, lo que facilitó la mediación y el acceso a la Casa Blanca. El objetivo principal de Estados Unidos era asegurar estabilidad y evitar un posible Estado fallido tras la salida

item.title: Homenaje a Inmaculada Ramos Tapia: un libro de memorias compartidas tras su fallecimiento
item.description: El artículo, escrito por Antonio Jiménez-Blanco Carrillo de Albornoz y publicado el 19 de enero de 2026 en Global Politics and Law, es una sentida necrológica en homenaje a María Inmaculada Ramos Tapia, profesora de Derecho Penal de la Universidad de Granada, fallecida en agosto de 2024 con menos de 60 años. Destaca su destacada trayectoria académica, especialmente su doctorado en el año 2000 sobre el delito de prevaricación judicial (publicado tras la sentencia del caso Gómez de Liaño-Prisa), así como su intensa labor en gestión universitaria y, desde 2023, en la Fundación Euroárabe de Altos Estudios en Granada. El texto resalta no solo su perfil profesional, sino también su personalidad vital, empática y llena de joie de vivre. Lo más novedoso es la iniciativa de su familia (marido e hijos) de publicar un libro titulado 'Memorias compartidas. Inmaculada Ramos en nuestro corazón', presentado en septiembre de 2025. item.title: Nani Roma agradece en 'La Revuelta' la labor de los sanitarios y denuncia sus bajos salarios
item.description:
El piloto catalán Nani Roma, una de las figuras más destacadas del automovilismo español, fue protagonista este miércoles en el programa 'La Revuelta', presentado por David Broncano en TVE. Durante la entrevista, Roma repasó algunos de los hitos más importantes de su carrera deportiva, entre ellos el haber ganado el Rally Dakar tanto en motos como en coches, un logro reservado a muy pocos. Sin embargo, el momento más emotivo de su intervención llegó cuando habló de su experiencia personal con la enfermedad.
En 2022, a Nani Roma le diagnosticaron un cáncer de vejiga, del que consiguió recuperarse tras un duro proceso médico que culminó con éxito en 2023, permitiéndole incluso volver a la competición profesional. A raíz de esta vivencia, el piloto quiso expresar públicamente su agradecimiento a los profesionales sanitarios que le atendieron durante su tratamiento.
Roma destacó la vocación y el compromiso de médicos, cirujanos y personal sanitario, subrayando que su trabajo no está sufi

item.title: Trump advierte sobre posibles represalias si Europa vende activos de EEUU
item.description: El presidente Donald Trump ha declarado que Estados Unidos respondería con 'grandes represalias' si los países europeos decidieran vender activos estadounidenses como reacción a sus amenazas arancelarias relacionadas con Groenlandia. La advertencia se produjo durante una entrevista en Fox Business en el Foro Económico Mundial en Davos. Trump afirmó que 'tenemos todas las cartas', aunque no especificó qué medidas concretas podrían adoptarse. La especulación surgió tras la planificación de un aumento de aranceles a productos de ocho países europeos, lo que podría haber llevado a Europa a vender billones en bonos y acciones estadounidenses. Esto podría afectar a los mercados financieros, ya tensionados por las intenciones de Trump sobre la isla ártica. El acuerdo marco que evitó la escalada incluye la promesa estadounidense de no imponer nuevos aranceles, la instalación de misiles en el territorio danés semi-autónomo y la regulación de derechos minerales para limitar la influencia china,

item.title: Siete hombres condenados a 97 años por violar a una joven en Zaragoza durante dos días
item.description: La Audiencia Provincial de Zaragoza ha condenado a siete hombres a un total de 97 años de prisión por la agresión sexual continuada de una joven durante dos días en junio de 2020 en un piso del barrio de San José. Los acusados estaban vinculados a la banda juvenil Dominican's Don’t Play. Según la sentencia, la víctima fue llevada al piso tras pasar la tarde bebiendo alcohol y consumiendo marihuana, donde se le obligó a mantener relaciones sexuales mientras se encontraba en estado de confusión y aturdimiento. Para justificar estas agresiones, los condenados alegaron un supuesto ritual de curación para “sacar el demonio” que la joven llevaba dentro. Varios de los actos fueron grabados con el móvil de uno de los agresores y descubiertos por la Policía Nacional durante la desarticulación de la banda en 2021. Los vídeos mostraban a la víctima quejándose y exhausta, mientras los agresores se reían de ella. Seis de los condenados recibirán 14 años de prisión cada uno, y el séptimo, 13 años, p

item.title: Los maquinistas denuncian déficit en el mantenimiento de vías tras el accidente de Adamuz y critican la priorización de grandes obras
item.description:
Los maquinistas del sindicato SEMAF han criticado duramente el mantenimiento deficiente de la red ferroviaria española, especialmente tras el grave accidente ocurrido en Adamuz (Córdoba) el 18 de enero de 2026, donde un tren Iryo descarriló y colisionó con un Alvia de Renfe, dejando un balance de 45 fallecidos y numerosos heridos. Teo Moreno, coordinador de comunicación de SEMAF, ha explicado que los profesionales reportan incidencias diarias por vibraciones en las vías, pero hasta ahora no se imponían límites de velocidad para no afectar la operativa de la alta velocidad, considerada la 'joya de la corona'. Afirma que fuera de España no se entiende que un aviso por vibraciones no conlleve restricciones inmediatas, y que estas vibraciones aceleran el desgaste de vías y trenes, creando un ciclo vicioso que puede llevar al colapso de materiales.

item.title: El FC Barcelona y su papel durante el procés catalán (2012-2017)
item.description: El estudio de Carlos Pulleiro Méndez analiza cómo el FC Barcelona se vio afectado y cómo reaccionó durante el procés independentista catalán entre 2012 y 2017. Lejos de ser un simple club de fútbol, el Barça combina su identidad histórica vinculada al catalanismo y la democracia con su transformación en una multinacional del deporte. El club mantuvo una línea de defensa de la libertad de expresión y del derecho a un referéndum pactado, sin apoyar explícitamente la independencia. Comunicados oficiales, declaraciones de dirigentes y jugadores, y decisiones como la presencia en actos de la Diada o el Concert per la Llibertat muestran una estrategia clara basada en valores democráticos y diálogo. El conflicto político se intensificó en 2017 con el referéndum del 1 de octubre y la declaración unilateral de independencia, momento en el que el Barça aumentó la intensidad de sus pronunciamientos públicos, condenando la violencia policial y defendiendo espacios de expresión política como el Cam

item.title: Desprendimiento de tierra en Mount Maunganui sepulta parte de un camping en Nueva Zelanda y deja varios desaparecidos, incluidos menores
item.description: Un masivo desprendimiento de tierra, causado por lluvias torrenciales históricas en la Isla Norte de Nueva Zelanda, arrasó durante la madrugada del 22 de enero de 2026 parte del camping Mount Maunganui Beachside Holiday Park, en la zona de Mount Maunganui (Mauao). El deslizamiento destruyó caravanas, tiendas de campaña, vehículos y el bloque de baños y duchas, sepultando estructuras bajo toneladas de lodo, árboles y escombros. Varios campistas, entre ellos niños de vacaciones con sus familias, quedaron desaparecidos, con un número confirmado en un solo dígito según las autoridades. Testigos describen escenas de pánico y destacan la actuación heroica de una mujer que, sobre las cinco de la mañana, recorrió el camping alertando a los ocupantes golpeando puertas para que evacuaran ante el riesgo inminente; lamentablemente, ella misma quedó atrapada en el edificio de servicios que fue destruido.
